title: 113_hr2226
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal and State Partnership for Environmental Protection Act of 2013". Consultation with states is required. The Act "Federal and State Partnership for Environmental Protection Act of 2013" requires consultation with states for removal and remedial actions under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980. Amendments include consulting with affected states for removal actions and specifying the process for selecting appropriate remedial actions. Amendments to the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 require consultation with affected states for selecting remedial actions. State and local officials must be consulted and given the opportunity to participate in the planning process. The selection of the response action must be documented in the administrative record. SEC. 3. STATE CREDIT FOR OTHER CONTRIBUTIONS. Section 104(c)(5) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 is amended to include provisions for non-Federal funds, oversight costs, and in-kind expenditures for removal or remedial action at a facility. This encompasses contributions of real property, equipment, goods, services, and recycled materials valued at fair market value. Section 104(c)(5) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 is amended to include provisions for non-Federal funds, oversight costs, and in-kind expenditures for removal or remedial action at a facility. This includes contributions of real property, equipment, goods, services, and recycled materials valued at fair market value. Amendments also specify expenses for removal or remedial action under this paragraph. State concurrence with listing on the National Priorities List is addressed in Section 4. The amendment to Section 105(a)(8)(B) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 requires the President to provide the basis for not including a priority on the revised national list to the State that submitted it. The President cannot add a facility to the national list if the State objects, unless certain conditions are met. The amendment to Section 105(a)(8)(B) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 outlines the criteria for including facilities on the national list, with considerations for state priorities. Additionally, states have the authority to designate facilities meeting specific criteria to be included on the national list every five years. Section 121(f)(1)(C) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 is amended to allow for adding and deleting sites from the list. Section 121(d)(2)(A)(ii) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 is amended to include State environmental covenant law in addition to State environmental or facility siting law.
